Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Neuromorphic device derived from resistive switching system
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in facilitating innovations in a wide range of industries working on advanced computing-based applications as the result of a reliable neuromorphic chip (where neural networks are etched into silicon). This technology may accelerate the advance of machine learning and ultimately realize a breakthrough in computing architecture by overcoming the Von Neumann bottleneck -- where the intrinsic latency originated from the separation of processor and memory. Empowered by neuromorphic features of this project's technology, machine learning may be carried out with unprecedented speed and efficiency in design and energy consumption. Hence, intensive machine learning based technologies such as face recognition, autonomous driving and other areas of artificial intelligence will be advanced by a significant margin. A successful execution of the project will also facilitate widespread commercialization of emerging applications utilizing artificial intelligence and/or neuromorphic computing.

This I-Corps project leverages the recent innovative research related to highly controllable neuromorphic devices. The technology is based on the oxide-based resistive random access memory (ReRAM), a non-volatile memory based upon electrical stimuli-induced resistance changes, mostly by the formation and rupture of so-called nanoscale conducting filaments in each cell. The intrinsic resemblance of ReRAM cells to neuromorphic systems triggered a recent boom in related research. However, there are still considerable technical issues including wide cell-to-cell variations in operation voltage, cell current and operation speed. Unclear understanding of physical switching mechanisms precludes a rationale design of reliable cells for a commercial device. The proposed novel scheme, in which the uncontrollability is significantly minimized, is expected to achieve a breakthrough in realizing commercializable neuromorphic devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We ultimately aimed to create a new ‘brain on a chip’ to replace conventional CPUs by leveraging our new technology of realizing few-nanometer non-volatile memory cells at scale. Our core technology addresses and resolves the primary problem of resistive switching device. Based on principles established through our research, we have developed our own chip design rules and material recipes. With the bottom-up approach we developed, a highly dense and reliable data storage with neuromorphic feature is possible. A successful implementation of this technology is likely to enable a widespread commercialization of next-generation chips for advanced computing for AI, autonomous driving and more.

During the NSF I-Corps program, we probed market landscape and performed customer discovery by interviewing more than 120 potential customers and partners in a wide range of value chain in semiconductor industries mainly located in the Silicon Valley and South Korea. From the interviews, we could identify ideal target segments and technological specifications of large potential customers, and eventually redefined our business model. From the customer development process, we became convinced that the next-generation chip market is around the corner. But we needed to pivot our customer segments from our initial target of Artificial Intelligence (AI) driven market to Industrial Internet of Things (IoT) market. We could also extract a more feasible business model: Since non-volatile storage in IoT is energy inefficient and slow, for product managers (VP or Director) of industrial IoT chip buyers/makers, we provide a semiconductor chip that guarantees the continuity of operation after downtime in automated factory. However, we decided to further develop our technology before making a major effort in commercialization based on the assessment of the technology level that is required to enter the market.

Once our goal achieved, our ‘brain on a chip’ is expected to dramatically impact not only on the computing world but also on humanity and society in several ways. Our project potentially has power to transform a human-being’s interaction with computers. At the last stage of our technology development, we could create the proximate device to the cognitive computing often featured in science fiction. One brain like chip would enable the machine to learn at scale, remember, reason with purpose or help humans make better decisions.
